newsitem.title: USA: Lakehead says FERC approves lower tariff.
newsitem.headline: Lakehead says FERC approves lower tariff.

text.p: Lakehead Pipe Line Partners LP said the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) on Wednesday formally approved a tariff rate agreement which provides for a reduction in current tariff rates of about six percent and total rate refunds and interest of $120 million.
Of the amount to be refunded, about $37 million will be paid in a lump sum in the fourth quarter of 1996, with the remainder repaid through reduced tolls over the next three years.
Of the rate refunds and interest accrued in 1996, $25.3 million is related to prior years.

Lakehead said if the prior years' effects of the accruals were removed from both nine month periods, recalculated net income per unit would be $53.7 million, or $2.18 per unit for 1996 versus $48.8 million, or $1.99 per unit for 1995.
Earlier Wednesday, the company reported nine month earnings of $28.6 million, or $1.15 per unit, versus $24.7 million, or $0.99 per unit.
Lakehead, a liquid petroleum pipeline owner, also said capital expenditures to September 30 totaled $52.5 million and are expected to total about $85 million for the entire year.

Most of this year's capital spending is for the partnership's 1996 system expansion. It will increase delivery capacity into Chicago area markets by up to 120,000 barrels per day at a cost of about $65 million.
